turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: You may keep the pearls -- I don't want them any more -- I'll make you a present of them.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I don't want them now.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I'll not denounce you.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: So --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Yesterday I was a thief -- but now, --

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: But now, you must go... I give you the pearls. But now you must go ---

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I wanted money desperately -- Can you understand? -- That's why I wanted the pearls. I was threatened -- I was desperately in need of a certain big sum of money. I've been following you -- I've admired you. But I have forced myself not to think about you -- Last night, at last, I managed to came into your room and -- and now.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: And now?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I couldn't go through with it.  Remarkable.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Do you understand?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Yes -- yes -- yes.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Grusinskaya --

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: You do believe that I really love you?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Yes -- If I didn't believe that, I'd die after last night.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I want to be good to you -- madly good.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Suzette will be back here in a minute.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'll go -- good-bye.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Shall I see you again?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Suzette will be back here any minute.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: When are you leaving Berlin?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Very early in the morning.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: For Vienna?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Can't -- can't you -- Couldn't you come too -- I think it would be better -- for us -- for us both.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Oh -- yes but -- later.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Why later?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I have no money now -- I must get some first -- I must get some.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I'll give you what you need -- I have money.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Oh no -- that would spoil everything. I'll -- I will manage somehow -- I'll manage myself. I will go with you. When does the train leave?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Six twenty-seven in the morning... But the money?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Never mind -- I'll get it. I have a whole day. I'll be on that train.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: You must go now. Be careful on your way to your room.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'll go. -- I love you.  I'll be on that train. I'll get the money.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Don't do anything foolish -- I'm alarmed about you.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Don't worry. I'll be on the train.  He leaves.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Bless you...

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Are you coming to the theatre? Oh -- I shall dance tonight -- How I shall dance -- I want to feel that you are in the theatre.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: No?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: No! I can't explain now. Oh, look -- the pearls. You wear them now...

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Why do you think --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: They've brought me such good luck -- you --

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: I'm worried about you.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Don't.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: On the train?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Yes -- I will be on the train.

turns.speaker: GRUSINSKAYA
turns.text: Till then.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Bless you --

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Not at all, sir.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Permit me -- my name is Kringelein -- from Fredersdorf.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'm Baron von Gaigern.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, a Baron!

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: And this is Doctor Otternschlag.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh -- Doctor -- you are a Doctor -- I am --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: What's the matter, Mr. Kringelein?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: General Director Preysing!  Baron, when I was sixteen years old, I started as an office boy in that man's factory --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Then you know him?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Do I know him -- I know him through and through.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Baron, we must have gone a hundred miles an hour, at least...

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Yes, quite.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: We've been together all day... and in an aeroplane.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'm going to change and we'll meet for a drink in the Yellow Room.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: In the Yellow Room, where the music's playing and the ladies are?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Where the music's playing and the ladies are...

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Hello -- sorry I'm late.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh -- here you are, Baron. A drink -- A Louisiana flip?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Hello, Mr. Kringelein. How do you feel now?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: A little strange, Baron.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: A drink, Baron -- A Louisiana flip?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: No thanks -- keeping my head clear.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: The Baron is tired?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: No, Kringelein, not tired, -- just --  Well -- well --

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Perhaps this evening, Baron, we could go to the Casino -- the place we passed with the marvelous bright lights?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I'd like to Kringelein, but I can't -- I am broke!

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Broke -- A Baron? But, Baron --

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Was the Baron joking, or is it really true that the Baron is -- in financial straits.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Absolutely true, Kringelein and I have to raise some money immediately.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: If the Baron -- if you would permit me --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I would be awfully glad to oblige, you've been so decent to me. Three hundred?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: If I could get into a game I might win some.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Gambling! I'd like that. I have over six thousand eight hundred marks with me.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: If we could scare up some men to play.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: We could come to my room.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Good!

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Ready, Kringelein?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Ready, Baron.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Is that too much, Baron?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: No -- not at all.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: All right then.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: All right then.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: That was my last.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: You've lost everything?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I've no luck.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Pardon me, Baron. Permit me again...

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Drink to me, Kringelein -- it's my last chance.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I do drink, Baron -- I drink to you, Baron and to win.  It's good, -- come along, Baron.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I take five hundred.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: All of that at once, Baron?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Here -- here it is. Here's your pocketbook, Kringelein.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh -- yes -- that's it -- you found it -- you found it for me, Baron.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Goodnight, Kringelein.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: No -- no please -- oh, don't go -- don't go -- don't leave me alone, Baron.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: You're all right now -- it's very late -- goodnight, Kringelein.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, no, stay here, Baron -- stay.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: Good evening -- my key -- one sixty- eight.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Good evening, Mr. Pimenov.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: Oh -- good evening, Baron.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: How's the beautiful lady?

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: Grusinskaya -- well, to tell the truth, Baron -- tonight we are a little bit nervous. Were you at the theatre last night?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Certainly -- always when Grusinskaya dances.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: Well -- last night was not so good.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I thought she was splendid!

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: Yes -- but the audience.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: It's always so quiet here.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: If you occupied the room next to Madam Grusinskaya, you would appreciate the quiet of a hotel lobby.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: My dear sir, I would gladly change rooms with you.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: No doubt you would, Baron. But do you know, I'm quite indispensable to her. I'm her ballet master and her nurse. I hardly belong to myself anymore. But, there you are, it's Grusinskaya -- you can't help adoring her.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: The war.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: That is Doctor Otternschlag -- You know him?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Yes -- He always seems to be waiting for something -- and nothing ever comes.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: The war dropped him here and forgot him.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Yes, I was in the war.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Perhaps you could present me now, Mr. Pimenov.

turns.speaker: PIMENOV
turns.text: Please, Baron -- forgive me -- not now -- here she is.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Pardon me, the lady has urgent business here with me.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Insolent -- Berlin manners.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Oh, let the poor devil alone.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I did not ask your advice.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I think it would be much better if you went away.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: We shall see who remains here the longer.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: As you will.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Aha! -- The Baron. What do you want here?

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: I must have made a mistake.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Made a mistake -- remarkable. We shall soon see if you made a mistake.   Stay here... Give me that money.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: So that's how we stand, Baron.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Look here, sir -- I'm completely at your mercy -- I'm desperate -- it's a matter of life or death -- I had to get some money -- tonight.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Indeed you must, Baron -- you must. Humm -- humm, but you must go to jail, Baron, you're a thief.

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Be quiet.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I'm going to call the police. I'm going to watch you play the great Baron with the police. Aristocrat! Aristocrat!

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Hello! Hello! --

turns.speaker: BARON
turns.text: Don't do that.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: Is that for me?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: No -- Madam Grusinskaya's car is to be brought.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car is to be brought.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: For me?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: No -- Madam Grusinskaya's car is not to be brought.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: Madam Grusinskaya's car is not to be brought.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: For me?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: No -- letters to two-eighty.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: If a young woman, a stenographer, -- etc.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The stenographer is to go up -- Mr. Preysing telephoned.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: Mr. Preysing -- one sixty-four.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Madam Grusinskaya -- at once --

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: Your chauffeur's been waiting, Baron.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The night clerk has already gone -- you are late.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: Man -- I was at the clinic the whole night -- there are no words to describe what my wife suffered.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: And the child isn't coming?

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: No -- no -- not yet. Well, I mustn't let it interfere with my duty. Any news here?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: News? Yes -- killing in number one- sixty-four.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: What? -- Who? -- Whom?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The big manufacturer killed Baron von Gaigern.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: Good heavens. What for?

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: Man -- that's terrible. He was a nice fellow -- I am sorry about him.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: It seems that he was a thief and an imposter.

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: I don't believe it -- he was a real gentleman. I know people... I'm so tired I can hardly see out of my eyes. No sleep for two nights and so many duties and now this killing in the hotel -- that means a lot of work. But it's too bad about the Baron, you always felt better when he came along -- always friendly -- such an agreeable fellow.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Most imposters are --

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any letters?

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: No, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Telegrams?

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: No, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Anyone asked for me?

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: Nobody, Doctor.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Any letters?

turns.speaker: SENF
turns.text: No, doctor.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I came here from a long distance to stay at the Grand Hotel. I want a room -- a big room -- like you would give General Director Preysing -- I'm as good as Mr. Preysing -- I can pay like Mr. Preysing -- would you give him a little room, way up in the corner with the hot water pipes going -- bang -- bang -- bang...

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: This gentleman can have my room.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Send his bags up to my room.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh -- but -- I --

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You're tired. I can see that.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes -- yes -- I am tired. I have been ill...

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You are ill.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I know -- I know -- when a man's collar is an inch too big for him -- I know he is ill.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes -- Oh -- oh -- yes, --

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: You will stay, Doctor -- if you have nothing better to do?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I have nothing better to do, Mr. Kringelein.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, but Doctor. Isn't this wonderful. To live -- to live -- in the Grand Hotel.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: The Grand Hotel.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, but Doctor. The music -- the champagne -- girls when they dance -- all the shining ice in those big silver things -- That's life --

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Life! -- Mr. Kringelein, you are drunk -- good night.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: But Doctor --

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Life is changing you, Mr. Kringelein.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes, thanks to the Baron. The best shops, the very best. Look, Doctor, silk -- feels so nice on the skin... a London hat, see -- made in England, that's silk, too -- fifty marks... Look, the price is on it. That was half my salary before. The Baron is a very fine gentleman -- no one in my life has been so nice to me as the Baron.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No pain, Mr. Kringelein?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Pain? Oh, no, Doctor. I think if I had pain I'd be too happy to notice it...

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Barman -- whiskey --  For you, Mr. Kringelein?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: For me? -- Oh, please, something sweet and cold.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Well, Mr. Kringelein, are you getting what you're looking for?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: What, Doctor?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: A masculine paradise -- drink, the ladies, dancing...

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I had a very good opportunity, a young lady asked me to dance -- I ought to be able to dance, it seems to be very important.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You must learn as quickly as your time allows -- Believe me Mr. Kringelein, a man who isn't with a woman is a dead man.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Haven't you anyone -- Haven't you anybody -- you -- I mean -- Are you all alone in the world.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I'm always alone -- I have been everything.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Everything?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I was sent as a military surgeon to South Africa. Stinking climate. Taken prisoner. Home on parole not to fight. I was a surgeon in the Great War till the end. Grenade in the face. Carried diphtheria bacilli in the wound until 1920. Isolated two years.  I've been everything.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Excuse me, gentlemen.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: I'll take the bank -- All right, gentlemen.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Over -- over so soon -- it has just begun.  Oh, the pain.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Try and sleep, Kringelein, don't be afraid.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I'd like to live a little longer but -- I'm not afraid to die -- I'm not...

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: There is no pocketbook here... On the floor probably.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: More than fourteen thousand marks... were in that pocketbook.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Fourteen thousand marks... One can travel -- one's happiness might depend on fourteen thousand marks -- don't you think so, Baron?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, I've got to find it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Stay where you are.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: No -- I must find it --  Fourteen thousand two hundred marks.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: You've nothing to fear, Kringelein

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: If I could trouble the Baron to come and see this beautiful room. I have ordered champagne. Perhaps the Baroness could join us.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Waiter, oh waiter! Wait a minute!  We are having caviar -- it's expensive but that makes no difference -- I see the Baroness is laughing.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Have caviar if you like, but it tastes like herring to me.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: You may laugh. Caviar and champagne may mean nothing to you, but to me -- they mean a great deal. You see, I'm ill and all of a sudden I got a fear of missing life. I don't want to miss life -- do you understand?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You are funny. You speak of life as if it were a train you wanted to catch.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes -- and for me, it's going to leave at any minute. Let's drink.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I'm sure this beautiful room must appeal to your taste -- distinctive, don't you think? Velvet upholstery -- 'A-number one'. I'm in the textile trade and I know.  And these are real silk drapes.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Silk -- think of that -- silk -- they are, too.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Have you seen the bathroom? -- Hot and cold running water -- You see, I can get a bath whenever I like.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Her master's voice!  I must go now -- goodbye -- thanks.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, don't go.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: I'm engaged for the evening.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, can anyone engage you for the evening?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: To take dictation -- a Mr. Preysing --  Goodbye, you -- tomorrow at five o'clock.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Good evening, Mr. Kringelein -- Where's the Baron?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I'm waiting for him here. The Baron and I have been together all day. A hundred miles an hour -- in a motor car -- and in an aeroplane -- It was marvelous --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Mr. Kringelein -- How you have changed, you look so nice.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, thank you, Miss Flaemm. Oh, please, Miss Flaemm -- Permit me, Miss Flaemm, won't you have something sweet -- a Louisiana flip.  A Louisiana flip.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: No - absinthe.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes -- that --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You like music?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes -- it's stimulating -- a man might --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: A man might what?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I don't know -- I'd like to do anything --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Oh -- you would!

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Dance then?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: She's beautiful -- isn't she?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You must look at my face and not at the floor.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You're trembling.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I never danced before -- in public.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You dance splendidly.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: I'm happy, Miss Flaemm.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: For the first time in my life, I'm happy.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Please -- please!

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: You don't like to see me enjoying myself.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Quick -- Mr. Kringelein.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh -- what -- what --

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh -- oh, Miss Flaemmchen. It's you --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Quick -- something awful -- awful has happened. Go -- go at once, -- Mr. Preysing --

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Preysing?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Oh -- I was thinking -- Poor Baron -- Lying there, his eyes so open.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: You loved the Baron, didn't you?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Yes --

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: So did I. He was friendly to me as no man ever was.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Perhaps he really was a burglar -- But they don't kill a man for that.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: He was in desperate straits. He'd been trying to raise money all day. He laughed -- Poor devil! And then a man like Preysing kills him.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: I didn't like Preysing right off.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Then why did you have anything to do with him?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Money!

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Yes, of course, -- money!

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You don't understand that do you?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Of course I do -- I never knew what money really meant till I started spending it. Do you know --  I can hardly believe that anything so beautiful should come to me from Preysing -- I'll take care of you. Will -- will you let me?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: You'll have a good time with me. Want to? I've got enough money. Ten thousand two hundred in my pocketbook. Three thousand four hundred that I won. It will last a long time. I can win more -- we'll travel.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Yes -- to Paris? I wanted to go there always.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Wherever you like. Here I'll give you the money I won, three thousand four hundred. Later you can have more.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Later?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: When I -- I'm ill, Flaemmchen -- It will not be long -- I'll not last long. Will you stay with me until...

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Nonsense! We'll find a great doctor, he'll cure you. They can cure anything these days.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Do you believe that you will have a better time with me than you would with Preysing?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Oh yes, of course.

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Do you like me better?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You're a good man, Mr. Kringelein -- a very good man.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Am I!

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Is the bill ready -- the lady's too?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: How do you know there is a Grand Hotel?

turns.speaker: KRINGELEIN
turns.text: Oh, there must be one in Paris... They have everything in Paris.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: What...! --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: I'm the stenographer.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Then you will please wait outside.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Moreover --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Moreover --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Moreover...

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Moreover...

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Do you work in Justice Zinnowitz' office?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: No -- only occasional jobs.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Tired?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You pay me.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You're a very unusual stenographer --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Moreover...

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Moreover...

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: I don't see why it's unusual for a stenographer to be pretty -- if she does her work well, -- seems so silly. I don't know why they don't like girls like me in offices. Personally, I hate offices -- I'd much rather be in the movies.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Movies?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Yes, I photograph very well. Look --

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: What is this?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: I got ten marks for that.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You...

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Me.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You...

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Moreover...

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Only in mutual advantages -- moreover.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: What brown hands you have.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: That's from skiing.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Skiing?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Yes... A man I know took me to Switzerland last month...

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: A man? -- To Switzerland? -- That must have been nice -- for him.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Only in mutual advantages -- moreover...

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Moreover... He was a lucky man -- that man.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Perhaps.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Don't misunderstand me. I'm a married man -- with grownup daughters. Uh --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Moreover -- Do you mind if I smoke?  I went to Florence once, too.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: With the same friend?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Moreover, the possibility of the successful termination of negotiations now pending with the Manchester Cotton Company...

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Not too quickly.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You're a little too fast.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Can't you understand me?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: I understand you perfectly.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Have you got it now?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Cotton Company --

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Should throw a great weight into the balance...

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: ...weight into the balance...

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: How nice -- your daughters?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: My daughters -- yes, my daughters.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Is that Mrs. Preysing.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Definitely off.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Oh -- too bad. Did you quarrel?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: That'll be all -- be here tomorrow at nine o'clock.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Miss Flaemm.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Hello!

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I must speak with you, Miss Flaemm.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Presently, Mr. Preysing.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: It's urgent.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Come and dance with me, Mr. Kringelein.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I must speak to you, Miss Flaemm -- business.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Tomorrow morning.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: No -- now.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Do you gentlemen know each other, Mr. Kringelein -- Mr. Preysing -- Baron von Gaigern.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Now, children, no fighting -- save that for the office. Let's have our dance.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I'll remember you, Mr. Kringelein.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Oh, yes, Mr. Preysing?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Sit here.  Cognac -- for you?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I'm going to keep an eye on that Kringelein fellow. I'll find out where he gets the money to hang around the Grand Hotel.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Well -- you want me?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I must go to England -- at once.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You see, I'd like to take a secretary with me for my correspondence and -- humm -- humm -- for company on the trip -- I'm nervous -- I need somebody -- I don't know if you quite understand me. You said you have travelled with gentlemen -- and I mean --

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: I understand perfectly.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: What do you think your salary would be -- for such a trip?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Wait -- I must figure it up.  First, I'll need -- clothes -- shoes -- it's cold in England in March, I'll need a suit... You'd want me to look nice?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Of course -- of course.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: A thousand marks --

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: It's agreed -- I will get a room here for you.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Can you pay some attention to me?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Oh, yes.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Insolent young cub!

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You mean Baron von Gaigern?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Baron!

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Well, he's a gentleman!

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You are late. I've been waiting for you -- waiting.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: I had to arrange about the trip.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You're sweet.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: You think so?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Come here.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Here, hold up!

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Oh -- careful, Mr. Preysing.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Call me -- do you know -- would you -- would you like to call me by my first name?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: Oh, no.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: I couldn't do that, you're a stranger to me.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: You're a funny little creature, Flaemmchen. I can't make you out.

turns.speaker: FLAEMMCHEN
turns.text: It's not funny at all. One can't get intimate just off hand. I could go to England with you and everything like that -- supposing I met you next year and I said: 'How do you do, Mr. Preysing! And you said:  'That was the young lady who was my secretary in Manchester'.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: And ask me what it's costing us to hammer it down.

turns.speaker: WAITZ
turns.text: Exactly.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: If the Preysing people get the Manchester contract, we shall certainly merge with the Preysing company -- but if they haven't they're ruined -- Preysing will have to declare himself.

turns.speaker: WAITZ
turns.text: Shhh -- here he is now.

turns.speaker: WAITZ
turns.text: Oh -- ho -- you want legal aid against us? -- The whole thing seems to me to be very simple.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Very simple -- I've always liked the way you dressed, Preysing -- English, isn't it?

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: What we want to know about is Manchester.

turns.speaker: WAITZ
turns.text: Yes, Mr. Preysing -- that's what we want to know.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: They turn out marvelous material in Manchester.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Manchester -- yes. Yes, yes, they do. Yes -- Now gentlemen shall we begin at the beginning? -- Have we cigars -- water and everything?

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: There's a lot of business to be done with the Manchester Cotton Company. They've the whole English market right in their hands. Have you any connections with -- Manchester?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: We have a good many connections in England, naturally.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: I mean with the Manchester people?

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: We are here to discuss our merger. Naturally I can make no statement at this time. We must begin at the beginning.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: All right.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Since, on the eleventh of June, this year -- when the first negotiations for a merger between our respective firms was entered into -- both parties have fully agreed that this merger can result only in mutual advantages.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Oh -- yes -- I beg your pardon!

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I'm laying before you the last general statement of our concern. Active capital, plant and machinery, raw material and finished product -- for instance -- mop rags --

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Mop rags --!

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: I'd like to wait for Justice Zinnowitz, before I commit myself.

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Oh -- Preysing, Preysing --

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: No water -- What a place!

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: All you have to do is phone for it.

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: Now to proceed with the projected merger, the advantages for the Saxonia are so obvious...

turns.speaker: GERSTENKORN
turns.text: Oh -- now let's talk like adults. You want to tell us now a along story of what your factory can do. We know all that you could tell us and if you tell the truth it wouldn't sound so good. When you first approached us...

turns.speaker: PREYSING
turns.text: We did not approach you.
